reviewText:
I thought it would be nice to write a straightforward review for those who appreciate it, because a lot of the reviews here so far just rely mostly on hyping up their experience to make the game sound good. Minimum is a fun and solid game, possibly on track to be the next big thing for PC shooters.

However, when looking at Minimum it’s hard to find anything terribly unique about the game after playing the games that make up its core. Honestly, it’s just a hodgepodge of mechanics different games: creep farming from MOBA/ARTS/ASS♥♥♥♥♥♥S, civilian escort from TFC (payload from TF2), armor tiers from Quake, in-game crafting from RPGs, etc. It’s a very minimalist style of game that still manages to not look like a piece of indie garbage (aka the game has an artstyle instead of just “I LOVE X TYPE OF GAME LET ME JUST COPY ALL OF THE AESTHETICS FROM IT”). It’s a very functional game and has lots of potential to be fun, but it’s just nothing terribly special and I can’t really give it a whole lot of praise for breaking any new ground.

“B-b-but it’s just fresh out of Early Access!”
Relax.

In a time where the shooter market is focused mostly on console shooters and CounterStrike, it’s good to see a multiplayer arcade FPS take the scene with the promise of a fun multiplayer experience. The game is very fair in terms of hardware specs and can run on a variety of semi-modern setups. Getting kills and watching your gun go from basic to a beast of warfare makes me grin. There are lots of weapons to choose from but your basic weapons are still VERY viable, and it’s very easy to get the weapons you think might be fun to play with by just playing the game. You can customize several class loadouts for plenty of situations, and there’s a little cash-shop for alternate skins if one so feels the need to grab one to be a special snowflake. The maps are for the most part well-designed: it’s easy to get from point A to point B and figure out the general and some specific nooks & crannies of a map within a single round. There aren’t any particularly terrible parts of the maps that I’ve played where one player has been able to lock down a certain area just by existing. A majority of the weapons are Unreal Tournament/Quake derived (more UT than Quake), and there are old standards and familiar faces returning like a grenade launcher, rail gun, lightning gun, shotgun, plasma, and so on.

It should be easy to deduce from the trailers and Steam page that you’ll be playing in third-person. It’s got controller support but I can’t imagine why anyone would want to put themselves at that much of a disadvantage for a team-based arena shooter with a twist. When playing in-game, the more kills you get, the more damage you weapon can do and in some cases, the wider of an area of effect it has. You counter this by building into two currently existing armor types (to start): Knight and Berserker. The former is focused on protection and anti-Titan ability at the cost of player speed, and the latter is focused on dealing damage and brawling other players at the cost of protection and health. Using these armor types, players have to work together to keep their Titan safe while doing whatever they can to destroy the other team’s Titan. When both teams have their Titans destroyed, the game goes into a “creep farming” phase where both teams hunt small creatures for personal resources to upgrade their weapons and armor, while each creep kill boosts your Titan’s power. There’s a Golden Creep that gives a very large bonus to a Titan’s power, and it can keep the field even if a team lacking in creep farm grabs it or be the key to victory for the dominant team.

However, there are some problems that plague Minimum. As with any game that has some element of MOBA/ARTS/ASS♥♥♥♥♥♥S in it, it’s easy for one guy to feed the other team and let them climb the armor tiers a lot easier (one game I played just recently had me and one other guy with 2+/1 KDR while the guy at the bottom of our team was 2/35 and it took us an age to move forward). It’s also easy to just have everyone completely forget about killing creeps and just have underpowered Titans keep brawling each other; conversely, it’s also easy to have one team completely remember and the other completely forget and have a super-fast game.

There are quite a few connection issues with the game because there are a lot of moments where I end up thinking that the game is peer2peer. Rubberbanding is prevalent everywhere, but most commonly with those who end up dashing around with melee only. This is generally frustrating because someone will just hold W into you and you’ll shoot him, and suddenly he’ll stretch behind you and you’ll miss that one shot needed to keep yourself alive. It’s probably the biggest issue I’ve got with the game so far because it’s really easy to abuse with the Taser Shotgun, which will segway into the next paragraph.

In terms of complaining about balance, I’m not a fan of movement-impairing effects. I haven’t had any problems with anyone using the Cryo Rifle, but the Taser Shotgun is simply frustrating to play against. It goes against the arena shooter maxim of having freedom of movement and is a carry-over from the MOBA/ARTS/ASS♥♥♥♥♥♥S themes of the game. I also am not a huge fan of the deployable player turrets because it’s particularly easy to deploy any time (beginning, middle, end) during a fight and at the very least make the job of a teammate getting an avenger kill for you that much easier.

“B-b-but they’ll patch it!”
“G-g-g-git g-g-gud!”
Relax.

Like any other multiplayer or co-op game, Minimum is best played with friends. I wouldn’t mind seeing a LAN option or true private server option in the future, and by the looks of it Minimum can have a bright future ahead of it. I just hope Human Head Studios doesn’t fall to the cries of the majority begging for melee-only hold +forward to win or some other vocal group. I also hope that those XP-based mod slots on weapons don’t become a thing. I really hope they don’t. I hope Human Head Studios learned from the mistakes of Loadout. I really hope they did.

All in all, even though I can’t really praise Minimum for setting any standards or breaking any new ground, I would recommend Minimum if you’re looking for a new yet familiar experience in the shooter market. I'm ready to see how Human Head Studios keeps Minimum going, and I hope it's in a good way.

reviewText: Not exactly sure what the official statement for the game is, but this game is essentially still in alpha or early beta stages. There are still many features not avaialbe yet, but the overall gameplay is smooth since it's very basic and runs off the Unreal Engine, matchmaking is decent (seerver browser available) and the skill ceiling is pretty high. The game is a twitch shooter but there are many different weapons you can customize to fit your play style. It has minecraft-like art so the design is really minimalist. It mixes fast 3rd person shooter action with MOBA elements you would see in games like League of Legends, Dota, etc.\nSo far, I'm loving the game and I hope the devs continue to support it, but so far it seems as though they are rolling out the updates and bug fixes (but there is still a lot of progress to be made).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access and all that but it is a fun game. There's just so much missing.

I was suprised to find out out how much this game really lacks when it comes to it's features. Basic stuff like soundeffects such as footsteps is screaming with their lack of pressence. As of writting this it seems they have lately put out a fair amount of updates with a hint about keeping the pace up. I hope that is so because this came have a huge potential if it gets the attention and love it needs.

Right now you are tossed into a minimalistic world with customizable loadouts where you run around fighting, gaining rewards and as the match progresses you use the rewards to craft armour. Each kill drops a powerup that strenthens your weapon up to five times. All lost each time you die though. At the same time you use 2 different pickups to create on the spot new armourpieces and upgrade them.
The weapons have two firemodes. Depending on which weapon secondary might not even be an attack. There's a shotgun that has a highjump skill as secondary that is excellent to get out of fights or evade enemies. Meleewise you get a sword from the start that has a dash on secondary and as it you power it up it goes from one single boring plain stick to a dualwielding glorious flailing wall of death. All that seems really fun and proves the developer aren't afraid to break the classic mold of run'n gun shooters so we might see some awesome stuff in the future.

Besides primary and secondary weapons you also have a slot for a device in the loadout. Here you equip grenades, turrets and mines. Not to much options yet but so far all I've tried have been useful and served it purpose.

When it comes to gamemodes there are as of writting this three to pick from.
-Team deathmatch, just as basic as it sounds really.
-Horde mode, coop battling against waves of bots which seems a bit unbalanced and strange as bots can spawn on top of you. Clearly far from done.
-Lastly we have the Titanmode. this is the gamemode held up as whats it all about. Two teams fighting against eachother over creeps to strengthen their titans and have it push into enemy base for victory.

With all this said and from what I can see in the interface I really hope this game can get it together and accomplish its goals. But I wouldn't recommend it as a must buy for anyone. Only those interested in seeing a game evolve should really buy it as it is now. Is it fun? Yes, but it is so incomplete and lacking in features that it really is for curiousity and willing to support you should buy the game. Not to actually play it. Better not burn out on it now and get to have all the funs later when it is more fun to be had.

reviewText:
Just as good as these brownies which is saying a lot.

chocolate Chip Cookie Dough Brownies
Ingredients:

BROWNIE LAYER:
3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) unsalted butter
1 1/2 cups bittersweet chocolate chips
1 cup granulated white sugar
1/2 cup packed light brown sugar
4 large eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1/2 teaspoon salt
1 cup all-purpose flour

COOKIE DOUGH:
3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) unsalted butter, room temperature or almost melted
3/4 cup granulated white sugar
3/4 cup packed light brown sugar
1/4 teaspoon salt
2 tablespoons milk or cream
1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste
1 cup all-purpose flour
1 cup miniature chocolate chips
additional miniature chocolate chips, if desired (to garnish the top)
Directions:

Prepare the brownie layer-
1. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Spray a 9x9-inch pan with nonstick spray, then line with a strip of parchment paper so that it covers the bottom and comes up two sides of the pan. Spray the parchment with nonstick spray too.
2. In a microwave safe bowl (or in the top of a double boiler or pan set on top of a pan of simmering water), microwave in 30 second bursts to melt butter and chocolate chips together until all is melted and smooth. Whisk in the sugars, then whisk in the eggs, vanilla and salt. Sift flour into the bowl and stir that in too. Scrape the brownie batter into the prepared pan. Bake for 25 to 30 minutes, or until the brownie layer is cooked through (toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean). Place the pan of brownies in the refrigerator to speed up the cooling process (or cool at room temperature and add the cookie dough layer later).

Prepare the cookie dough layer:
3. In a large bowl, use an electric mixer to combine the butter, sugars and salt until soft and creamy (1 to 2 minutes). Mix in the milk and vanilla. Sprinkle in the flour and mix in until combined. Stir in the 1 cup of chocolate chips. Scoop the cookie dough onto the top of the brownies and spread onto the brownie layer. I find that it's easiest to do this if the brownie layer is chilled and firm. Wet your hands or spray them with nonstick spray and pat the cookie dough on top in a even layer. Sprinkle additional chocolate chips on top to create a nicer, visual appearance. For easy, clean cutting, chill the brownies (wrap the brownies with plastic wrap and chill until firm- 1 to 2 hours or up to 2 days).
4. Cut the brownies: Run a knife along the sides of the brownie pan and then use the parchment paper to lift the brownies from the pan and onto a cutting board. Slice the brownies with a sharp knife, wiping the knife with a paper towel between cuts. If you'd like all of your slices of brownies to look clean-cut without edges, use the knife to cut the sides of the brownies off before cutting pieces. Keep brownies slices covered and chilled until ready to serve.

reviewText:
I would take any complaints about balance issues with a grain of salt.  Yes, if you're caught out of position by a sword-wielding opponent, you're dead.  Launchers are excellent on small maps where players tend to bunch up and are vulnerable to splash damage.

On the other hand, if you pay attention to enemy positions and fight at range, swords are useless.  If you stay out of big melees and work the angles, launchers can be countered.  If there's any area where there are balance issues, I'd say it's in the armors.  A big portion of the armor selections are next-to-useless.  Which would you rather have: a helmet that gives a 5% damage bonus for shotguns and rifles, or a helmet that gives a 5% damage bonus for you AND all your nearby teammates for ALL WEAPONS?  Could use some tweaking.

Strategy and teamwork are very important in this game.  Combining weapon loadouts that synergize, and choosing the right armor can make the difference between a useful loadout and one that can't get anything done.  I really appreciate how leveling up and unlocking new weapons and armor opens up new styles of play, while the starting weapons and armor never stop being useful.  Sticking together with your team is critical, as it's almost impossible to win a two-on-one fight (if your opponents know what they're doing anyway).

The map design is great.  Mobility and positioning are a key element of strategy, particularly on Titan maps, which have opportunities for sword ganking, sniping, and everything inbetween.

Personally, I've been waiting for a game to attempt this kind of art style for a long time.  It's very reminiscent of Mirror's Edge, so if you like the visual style of that game, you'll enjoy the look and feel of Minimum.

That said, it really shows that the game is still in development.  There aren't a lot of servers, the automatching often puts you on servers with no players, I've exprienced some audio/visual bugs, and I'm pretty sure the Pickup Hell" weapon
date: that claims to make creeps drop more items
recommended: doesn't actually do what it says.  On one of the Titan maps
hoursPlayed: I fell into a crack and was stuck until an opponent killed me (The Event).  I would like to see more maps

reviewText:
The devs think it is Okay to make the game impossible to play for everybody for 7 months and delete their progress.

You can now log on and play matches. However, it may take about 15 minutes to find a match. You can only press the automatch button once per game, meaning that you have to close everything down inbetween matches, which is even more problematic as the quit button itself doesn't do anything, so the only way to exit the game is through the task manager, which you are forced to do every time you want to play.

The game itself will get repetitive and boring after a few hours. You can grind to unlock new weapons, but if you try and do that then the devs will probably reset everybodies progress again. Also, you can expect a myriad of bugs such as the game freezing for a few seconds multiple times each match.

0/10 Minimum enjoyment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game is terrible. At the moment the game is in beta, Its an interesting 3rd person shooter/slasher mobaesc game. 5 v 5 (if you are lucky) protect your giant robot so he destroys the base game.

Pros
+No Lag issues
+Interesting Art Style
+Awesome powerup system
Cons
-One team can easily dominate over the other, especially in a 4v5 situation.
-snowball issue. If one guy gets a bunch of temporary powerups on his weapon(which are gained from kills). He easily dominates the game about 2 minutes in.
-No leave penalty (Beta issue that should be resolved)
-Matchmaking. I do not know if there is any, but my last match I played was very imbalanced. Enemy teams user level was 5+ while my team was 3 or less. Felt like Call of Duty matchmaking.
-Melee weapons might need a nerf or ranged need a buff. Many times I peppered an enemy just to have him walk up to me and cut me down in one swing.
-Only main game mode (Titan Mode) is avaliable.

For a while I enjoyed it. The game is fun but what turned me off from it was how the handle the player drop in system. Its very counter mobaish but it made no sense to me. In one game a large amount of people just quit out. Which left the game 3 v 4 (my team having the 3). I go along play against the heavly leveled stacked team. Learning the trick to toss a grenade straight down to kill them off after they cut you in half with one swing. I then take a look at the scoreboard. It turned into a 3 v 5! How the hell does that happen?! No one joined my team at any point. I was always waiting for that balancing player to come in and help the team out but that never happened. It was depressing.

Maybe down the line I will give it another try, but as of now. It is a 1/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its an early acess game no doubt about that, but the gameplay is a lot of fun.
There arent many multiplayer third person shooters out there that i enjoy, tribes ascend being the only exception.

Things i like about this game.
- Ingame progression with craftable armour during matches:
ex: less health for more damage, less health for speed etc...
- allows for unique builds way more unique than other TPSs.

- Main Weapon upgrades upon killing an enemy
- forces you to be on the ofensive.

- Art style
- while minimilistic you can indentify what kind of armour the enemy has and know what kind of build they are making.

- Progression outside of a match
- with the 3 resource types you gain when playing you can craft new weapons and in the future slot in upgrades in them.

Things i dislike about this game.
- Balance
- theres some severe balance issues on some weapons nothing that can`t be fixed with time.
- Few game modes
- Lack of a proper match making
- Bugs

These things i dislike are usual with early acess games im sure they can be fixed with time, however i can say the game is stable in its current state ive been able to play with ease.

So if you are looking for a cool online TPS to play with your friends this is the game for you, if your still unsure after what`ve said then wait until the game is released. Cheers and happy gaming ;)

reviewText:
Minimum is a game where players in teams of five fight against another team, upgrading weapons, armor and their titan. Each team has one titan, which respawns shortly after death, and it's up to each team to defend their titan, while attacking the other, in the hopes of pushing their titan towards victory. It's a dynamic variation on the 'ARTS/MOBA' formula.
This game style works great, and is a tonne of fun but there are a few issues that need to be brought up.
1. Nobody likes to communicate in this team game where co-operation is nearly always vital to victory.
2. The game gives you the opportunity to get kills (which lets you upgrade your weapons and equipment while simultaneously getting score), or focus on killing or upgrading the titans (which lets you win the game). Being a video game, played by imperfect people, people often focus on getting kills instead of winning the game.
3. It's really quite irritating that a player needs to grind to try out new things, and considering the fact that the balance can often end up wonky, it feels like Minimum asks for too much time.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
(In future, I may rewrite this review, as currently I am posting it with a view to those considering Minimum while on sale, and so need to write it quickly. My views on the game would remain the same, however.)
To sum up my opinion: Although much of its content remains unimplemented, Minimum currently is a robust game that is quite well made and enjoyable to play. Be aware, however, that you will have to make an account with the game in order to play (or, at least, it was required at some point in the game's life).

I bought this game shortly after it came out of Early Access, as it sounded to me like it kept the elements I enjoy of MOBAs while adding in the aspects of team-based shooters that I enjoy more. And, for the most part, Minimum does so.

-What exactly is this game?
Sort of a cross between the standard MOBA and TF2, in my experience. There are three gamemodes, Titan, Deathmatch, and Horde. Horde can be somewhat confusing and is geared towards co-op (perhaps a bit like Mann vs. Machine in TF2) while Deathmatch is the standard shooters game type. Minimum's main uniqueness comes from Titan mode, a 5v5 format where each team attempts to activate and protect their Titan mech as it battles the enemy Titan and breaks through enemy defensive walls, eventually shattering their base to win the match. Although each Titan has a massive amount of health, players are able to deal noticeable amounts of damage to them if left unhindered, so each team will usually be fighting one another while the Titans are battling themselves. After both Titans have been destroyed, each team begins collecting charges by killing creeps located between the team bases. Whichever team obtains more charges for their Titan has an innate advantage in the next Titan battle, or 'Clash'. Games can last varying lengths of time depending on how many Clashes are required to break the enemy base, but in my experience they are usually on the order of 10-20 minutes, possibly 30 on the outside, similar to a round of Payload or Attack/Defence in TF2.

-What do I do in this game?
Mainly, players run around and shoot Titans, creeps, and each other. There are no set classes, but as is common in shooters, players set loadouts of weapons and gadgets before matches and then may quick-swap while in-game. Also, there is an armor system- each player can craft a head, torso, and leg armor from materials dropped from various sources or found around the maps. These armors usually grant either a situational bonus, such as increased speed at low health, a weak all-around bonus, such as reduced bullet damage, or a strong bonus paired with a potent downside, such as significantly increased health but much lower speed.
The weapons are mainly what you would expect in a shooter- sniper rifles, shotguns, assault rifles, miniguns, and launchers, along with melee weapons in the form of swords. There are some interesting subtypes of these weapons, however- for example, their are shotguns with forward dashes or high-jumps as altfire options. Another of Minimum's important systems is the weapon upgrade mechanic- every killed player, and certain other entities, drops an upgrade part. Picking this up increases the power of the currently equipped weapon, up to five times if I remember correctly. Most or all of these upgrade levels are lost on death.
-That sounds somewhat unbalanced for some players to have powered-up weapons and others not in a shooter. Also, aren't those melee weapons overpowered, like many have said?

Occasionally, yes, but in my experience most times good aim and possibly suprise can take out any player, even if they possess a maxed gun, as they will still have roughly the same health as any other player. Yes, they have an advantage in drawn-out fights or in ambushes, but when they die, they feed that advantage to other players. And in their own respect, katanas are fairly reasonable- it takes several swings to kill another player, and should they escape out of range, you are extremely vulnerable, as the distance-closing dash on the basic katanas has a recharge time. Shotguns especially are highly effective against melee enemies. As is often the case in multiplayer games, if the teams are heavily imbalanced or if every person on one team is using the same weapon, things can become annoying and unfair, but most of the time, Minimum is as balanced as any other team-based game.

-How are the graphics?

Although not intensive, Minimum has some beautiful visuals, in my opinion. As the title might suggest, they are often minimalistic, but they come across much as the best pixel art does, vibrant, elegant and clear simultaneously. The colors are quite nice, the Titans look great, and the weapons and projectiles all match the art style well. Character movement and reload animations are perfect most of the time, and are animated in substantial detail. And, each map feels unique, with its own movement lanes and seperated levels, paths and flanking routes, and eye candy, such as Japanese designs or industrial machines. The only real problem I have is that the player characters are rather empty, being just pure white cube people, until armor is equipped, after which they look somewhat more detailed.
-Final Notes
Minimum has a reasonably long-term item unlock mechanic, where each completed match earns you XP and resources. Each time you level up, you may unlock one new item blueprint, which can be crafted with enough resources. Without playing all that much, I have unlocked enough weapons to enjoy myself, but it takes quite a while to unlock everything. For the most part, you may not purchase resources with real money, so it is mainly fair to all players, although it seems that purchasing a reskin of an item with real money may grant the item, even should you not own the normal version.

At least at release, Minimum required the creation of an account with a back-end manager called Mber, which syncs with Steam and does not require much attention beyond initial setup.

Finally, many of Minimum's future mechanics, such as weapon modification, are not implemented yet, even though the game is out of Early Access, the daily tasks and menu screens could still use some work to function better, and, at least for me, the game occasionally crashes when attempting to exit. However, the devs have shown consistent support of their game and have continued implementation of the content they have promised, and have repaired many of the bugs since the game's release.

Especially at 75% off, I would highly recommend Minimum as an enjoyable, well-made team shooter with much potential.

reviewText:
Personally I would rate this game 8.5/10 since all the issues regard lag and crashes have been fixed.

Pros:
-Fun game
-Good mix of teamwork and soloing
-Fixed lag and server crashes
-Graphics are as advertised :P
-Every weapon is unique
-Every weapon is over powered when they reached maxed
-All weapons feel pretty balanced
-Your primary weapon levels the longer the match lasts (ex. if you die after the first 5 minutes, your weapon will be level 2, and it will be level 3 if you die after the first 8 minutes)

Cons:
-Unbalanced when its expierenced vs newer players
-Not many maps, but its a game still in beta
-They need to make base camping more punishable or some sort of turrent protecting spawn area
-Game was planned to be Free to Play
-Half of the armors need to be reworked due to the fact they are often useless compared to others.

Overall:
-Game is entertaining and quite enjoyable
-Consider reworking armor
-Looking forward to it when it comes out of beta
-A game worth trying and great with friends
-Game may be blocky but graphics look great
-Wish more people would check out some guides for the game


Other thoughts:

The game is perfectly balanced until more experienced players fight newer players. This is when it becomes unbalanced. The more experienced players tend to work together rather than running solo. This ends up making the the newer players having a difficult time being able to compete. In the end, the newer players get pushed back into spawn until they all move out together which often end up killing the geared experienced players. Several times me and my friends almost beat the enemy team in the first titan clash where we would usually break the first wall and do some damage on the second. We all knew what to do and how to start off while the other team didn't. You can solo pretty well, but if your team isnt working together, you will often loss.

As for the swords being overpowered, it is both true and false. Swords do great amount of damage but their reach is somewhat short. To counter this, just carry a loadout with taser shotgun or cryo sniper, this is a perfect counter to all melee users. One or two shots will stop them in their place, keep your distance and finish them off with another weapon, the slow effect last about 4 seconds  which is enough to finish them off. You could also just stay near a friendly turrent which can be used as a decoy to distract the enemy and finish them off.

reviewText:
Minimum is a neat little game with a nice art style and fast paced fun multiplayer, that is not to say, however that it is without problems. Although there is a nice variety of choice for melee and ranged weapons, it's only once you begin to observe the interaction through playing the game that you start to notice the problems with balance.

Firstly, although the swords are a nice edition it makes the gameplay in multiplayer somewhat frustrating as there is little balance of ability to defer a sword attack if you have a ranged weapon, especially with people spamming the jump button every second (I will return to this point). The problem you get particularly with this is that you will damage a sword wielder to close to their death but with all the hopping around they do, ultimately they will run around an object that covers them before running back out with recovered health and quickly spamming to kill you.

The second major problem stems from some of the purchased armour which to an extent makes parts of this game Pay to win" wherein I have seen people buying outfits to make them jump higher over and around players with large weapons making them very hard to hit and avoid their attacks due to their ability to jump far higher than any other average player
date: this is a serious problem in terms of combat balance in multiplayer as it means that not only can they jump above you and kill you faster
recommended:
but it also means that they can escape to areas you would not be able to access as easily yourself without paying for the same privelege of armour.

Bar this the gameplay is very fun and engaging and there is a lot of potential for great things once player balance is focussed on a little more.

Currently 5/10 with potential to be 8 or 9/10."

reviewText:
[BRIEF]- Minimum is a great, fast-paced, well-rounded 3rd person shooter. I have recommended this game to several of my friends. This is a cheap shooter game that stands out from other games such as CoD and BF simply because it's a geometric-like game. A game can have blocks without being compared to Minecraft, so let it go. The developers chose to do this sort of art style most likely for two common reasons: They wanted to stand out and they wanted to spend more time on the engine. The game runs very well on my computer, the servers are 90% reliable, and there are many more features that are currently being implemeted in the game.

[MICROTRANSACTIONS]- I'm sick of them, you're sick of them, he's sick of them.. who isn't? The developers have cut the price of the game from $20 to $10. They need the extra cash. At the time of me writing this review, they are purely cosmetic aswell. Each cosmetic" item in this shop has an equivalent that can be obtained by playing the game.

[GAMEPLAY]- I love this game. It runs so smoothly! I was amazed that the game was actually exactly how the trailer showed. I have enjoyed a couple of hours playing this game and I play on spending many more. It's like a mixture of Call of Duty
recommended: and League of Legends.\n\n[GRAPHICS]- The game is pretty. It's not meant to have top-notch graphics

Anyone that has played Minimum for at least 15 minutes can honestly say that the swords are too op. I believe that swords should be at least half of the power that they currently have. I have purchased the grenade launcher and the fork launcher

reviewText:
Review: Alpha State and Focus on Low Skill Kills

First the good things. The game's graphics are, at least for my taste, very nice. And the low poly design, along with some more optimizations, could allow this game to have very low system requirements. It's potentially the only recent shooter i could run at a constant and stable 120fps/hz.

A little downside here, the game seems to be locked at 90 fps, which is a bit sad in times of 120Hz monitors. Probably an engine limitation, but most likely one that could be changed. Maybe even in the config files if one looks for it.

Also, the combination of a shooter with a moba, is extremely nice. Huge addictive potential here. The Titan game mode is spot on and could even survive as a single gametype in a shooter.

Unfortunately, that's already all good there is to say for the moment. So now to the weak sides.

First of all, they claim to have left early access. But this game is not even in Beta stage. In a Beta, most of the features are already there. In this game most feats are still placeholders. So what we got here is an alpha build.

The game's weakest point is, unfortunately, the combat part. Everything you found in the past 10 years in serious shooters, that was counted by top players as skill free, honorless or plain trolling, is what Minimum promotes at the moment.

That the weapon sounds, like the AR, sound like pea shooters, could be forgiven. But that the strongest tactic" ingame is

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the only early access games I have bought and it was because it was just so appealing. I was skeptical about it but I bought it and I am so ♥♥♥♥ing happy with it. The game definitely is still in early access and you can tell, there are buttons, tabs that don't go anywhere just yet, there are certain elements that will become crucial in the game that haven't arrived. But nevertheless the game still has a lot to offer at this point and will only continue to grow.

The art style, game modes, weapons + weapon customization (only a bit of customization), controls and gameplay are all really fantastic. I have a blast playing the two modes they have in game currently which is the titan mode and the team deathmatch mode. The only thing I'm fearful of is microtransactions. I have not looked up if they are going to add microtransactions but just by the way that you buy weapons which is the these little cubes that act as currency, I can't help buy think that they may add it. Either way this is a great game and has a lot of potential in the future. I give it a 7.5/10 for this stage in its early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So i first played this game during an open beta weekend before they came to early access and pretty much instantaniously fell in love with it, the simple graphics, gameplay, the way the weapons handled, i could see they were heading into a good direction with the game.
the 18 euro price tag on it felt a bit steep though so i waited till they'd fixed a few things and suddenly the price dropped.
at 10 dollars/euros and 7pounds sterling it's definitely worth it, it's still in early access though, so for those who dislike a game with bugs and want a finished product, feel free to wait till you're comfortable with the state it's in (something that goes for all early access titles)
this game does deserve a massive boost in popularity as it seems to be a very over looked and could use more people playing it.

can't wait to see what else they'll be adding to the game! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A normal match for me in MINIMUM
Choose Katana Loadout
Hold Shift
Click people with my Katana
Get full Beserker armor loadout
Upgrade it
Click people with my dual flaming katana's
Run away when I'm just about to die and survive
Then get blasted by a random grenade
Rinse, and repeat.

...That may sound boring, but it's incredibly fun.
If you want a game where you can just click people with swords while they're shooting you and kill them with barely enough health, get this game! It's quite fun. :3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minimum gives players exactly that. A bare minimum game without any high resolution details or environments because it doesn't need them. On it's own it already outshines other titles of the same genre. With objectives and game modes so simplisitc all that needs to be done is grab your gun and run into action. Titan Mode pits two mechanical behemoths against one another as players run around collecting crystals to help stengthen their massive ally all while blowing away the opposite team in blocky destruction. Customizable loadouts, armor selections and schematic crafting add to strategy and overall enjoyment.
More than worth the money and with future improvements already on the way, this can only get better.

A few suggestions for the devs
- Implement a proper level matching system. Basically pitting players together of the equal level and skill.

- Block off spawn containers once a player exits them. Too many people exploit the invulnerable aspect of them and shoot others while protected. Or at least prevent shooting from within them.

- Lower sword melee damage. Base damage on swords seems a bit OP for single blades, dual blades can be an exception.

- Armor crafting should be a sperate loadout option same as weapons. This can allow players to know what they want ahead of time and not hold up their teams with decisions. Armor leveling should be done at the respawn screen.

- Tweak gun accuracy

- Add interchangable mods to weapon loadouts

reviewText:
Oh my god. Why. This game is borderline BROKEN. Well first, this game is fun BUT ONLY WHEN PLAYING HORDE MODE!!! Horde mode is really the only mode that doesn't have Level 5 Katana rushers charging at you every minute. Katanas are what breaks the game.

Reasons:
Level 1 Katana takes 3-4 strikes to kill.
Katanas make you impossible to hit especially when the frames are down, but I'll ge to that.
Katanas give you a speed boost.
WHAT WERE YOU THINKING?!?!?! Absolutely not! How I think this situation should be remedied. Katanas give you a -30% health detriment. No speed bonus. (Why would you need a speed bonus when your katana has a built-in dash function already?)

Okay, I think I've covered the Katanas. Now onto the snipers. VERY, VERY HARD. Do not come into this game thinking you'll be blowing robot's heads off left and right. No. The headshot hitbox is TINY. Honestly, come on. You're zooming around the battlefield at 30 MPH and the hitbox is literally the size of the head, which I get, because why should you be able to kill someone with a headshot when it would normally go right past their ear? Well, it's impossible to hit. And snipers take 2-3 shots to kill.
How to remedy: Snipers get a 40% faster rate of fire. PLEASE IT IS SO SLOW. Second, Make a sniper 1-2 shot kill. Third, expand the headshot hitbox.

Okay, now those frames I was talking about.
My computer is overkill when it comes to this. Specs: Processer-3.16ghz Graphics-Radeon HD7790. More than enough? Yes. Soo, why am I getting choppy frames? I can play Battlefield 3 at 60FPS on Ultra, and this simple graphical game can only run at 30 fps avg with 10 fps frame drops? C'mon... I think this should have stayed in Beta a bit longer to smooth out these problems.

I wouldn't advise buying this game until a patch comes in because you'll just end up screaming and throwing your mouse at the wall.

But it is a fun game, just really, really, broken!

reviewText:
Minimum is a neat little game with a nice art style and fast paced fun multiplayer, that is not to say, however that it is without problems. Although there is a nice variety of choice for melee and ranged weapons, it's only once you begin to observe the interaction through playing the game that you start to notice the problems with balance.

Firstly, although the swords are a nice edition it makes the gameplay in multiplayer somewhat frustrating as there is little balance of ability to defer a sword attack if you have a ranged weapon, especially with people spamming the jump button every second (I will return to this point). The problem you get particularly with this is that you will damage a sword wielder to close to their death but with all the hopping around they do, ultimately they will run around an object that covers them before running back out with recovered health and quickly spamming to kill you.

The second major problem stems from some of the purchased armour which to an extent makes parts of this game Pay to win" wherein I have seen people buying outfits to make them jump higher over and around players with large weapons making them very hard to hit and avoid their attacks due to their ability to jump far higher than any other average player
date: this is a serious problem in terms of combat balance in multiplayer as it means that not only can they jump above you and kill you faster
recommended:
but it also means that they can escape to areas you would not be able to access as easily yourself without paying for the same privelege of armour.

Bar this the gameplay is very fun and engaging and there is a lot of potential for great things once player balance is focussed on a little more.

Currently 5/10 with potential to be 8 or 9/10."

reviewText:
First of all I'd like to thank the devs. You guys deserve every penny you get for this game.

This game is worth way more then $10 bucks. Just buy it and stop wasting time reading comments. If $10 is all you got, spend it here.
This is the shooter I've been looking for.
I highly recomend this game. It has found a balance between simplicity and amazing value.
It has just the right amount of customization (not too much to slow you down and enough to keep you entertained for a long time) and you can be a totally different fighter every match.
Pros:
You don't need a great computer to enjoy the great things this game has to offer. Just tone down the settings a bit if your computer is outdated (the way this game is setup, it looks pleasing on any setting).
Good developers who actually give a **** about player's opinions.
Cool game modes (I like titan fights but I play team deathmatch just as much).
Good bots (actually fight and folow objectives and are coded pretty well).
The leveling and scavanging system are setup better than any shooter I've played so far (and thats saying a lot considering the amount of time I've played shooters when I used to be a console peasant).
Cons:
Bots (NPCs used to fill lobby's when not many players are on your current server) say the same things over and over and are slightly annoying. They things they say seem like slightly realistic peasant comments, so you won't notice in the beginning.

They say things such as:
launchers op"
"niice"
"sword noob"
"damn"
"lol"
"XD"
"yeeeeaaaaa"
"go team" - they say this even if there losing

................................................


-Like I said
recommended: this game deserves every penny (and more) of the measly $10 it asks for and will easily pay you back ten-fold if you give it your time. Also consider the fact that there will be more added
hoursPlayed: but you don't need to worry about that because this game is great as is. Please buy this game so we can have even more players and allow this game to live for a good while because it deserves it."

reviewText:
Personally I would rate this game 8.5/10 since all the issues regard lag and crashes have been fixed.

Pros:
-Fun game
-Good mix of teamwork and soloing
-Fixed lag and server crashes
-Graphics are as advertised :P
-Every weapon is unique
-Every weapon is over powered when they reached maxed
-All weapons feel pretty balanced
-Your primary weapon levels the longer the match lasts (ex. if you die after the first 5 minutes, your weapon will be level 2, and it will be level 3 if you die after the first 8 minutes)

Cons:
-Unbalanced when its expierenced vs newer players
-Not many maps, but its a game still in beta
-They need to make base camping more punishable or some sort of turrent protecting spawn area
-Game was planned to be Free to Play
-Half of the armors need to be reworked due to the fact they are often useless compared to others.

Overall:
-Game is entertaining and quite enjoyable
-Consider reworking armor
-Looking forward to it when it comes out of beta
-A game worth trying and great with friends
-Game may be blocky but graphics look great
-Wish more people would check out some guides for the game


Other thoughts:

The game is perfectly balanced until more experienced players fight newer players. This is when it becomes unbalanced. The more experienced players tend to work together rather than running solo. This ends up making the the newer players having a difficult time being able to compete. In the end, the newer players get pushed back into spawn until they all move out together which often end up killing the geared experienced players. Several times me and my friends almost beat the enemy team in the first titan clash where we would usually break the first wall and do some damage on the second. We all knew what to do and how to start off while the other team didn't. You can solo pretty well, but if your team isnt working together, you will often loss.

As for the swords being overpowered, it is both true and false. Swords do great amount of damage but their reach is somewhat short. To counter this, just carry a loadout with taser shotgun or cryo sniper, this is a perfect counter to all melee users. One or two shots will stop them in their place, keep your distance and finish them off with another weapon, the slow effect last about 4 seconds  which is enough to finish them off. You could also just stay near a friendly turrent which can be used as a decoy to distract the enemy and finish them off.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Here's an overall tiny review of what I think of the game. If you feel like reading one with more content though head over to  RealGamerReviews  [realgamerreviews.com]

NOTE
The game has been updated twice since my review was posted, and some of the things in my review actually got addressed. This includes some server issues, weapon maximization, deployables and structures (although the last two are only available in horde mode for now).

Overall Impression
This is a great game once you get past the short comings of weapon balances and the sometimes poor server connections. The weapons, despite their balance issues, are fun to use and there are several varying weapons to choose from. Titan mode now feels like it has actual depth and also promotes teamwork much better than its first itteration. If you have some friends and are looking for a game to kill time with then this is a great choice.

reviewText: Don't let the term MOBA scare you away. It's more like a MOBA-lite. Kill enemies to power up your weapons, die and they're reset to level 1. Kill neutral creeps during the creep phase to power up your titan, then defend your titan/destroy the enemy titan during the rampage phase. Or just deathmatch and ignore the objective. Either way, lots of fun. If you're looking for a new MOBA, look elsewhere.

reviewText:
[BRIEF]- Minimum is a great, fast-paced, well-rounded 3rd person shooter. I have recommended this game to several of my friends. This is a cheap shooter game that stands out from other games such as CoD and BF simply because it's a geometric-like game. A game can have blocks without being compared to Minecraft, so let it go. The developers chose to do this sort of art style most likely for two common reasons: They wanted to stand out and they wanted to spend more time on the engine. The game runs very well on my computer, the servers are 90% reliable, and there are many more features that are currently being implemeted in the game.

[MICROTRANSACTIONS]- I'm sick of them, you're sick of them, he's sick of them.. who isn't? The developers have cut the price of the game from $20 to $10. They need the extra cash. At the time of me writing this review, they are purely cosmetic aswell. Each cosmetic" item in this shop has an equivalent that can be obtained by playing the game.

[GAMEPLAY]- I love this game. It runs so smoothly! I was amazed that the game was actually exactly how the trailer showed. I have enjoyed a couple of hours playing this game and I play on spending many more. It's like a mixture of Call of Duty
recommended: and League of Legends.\n\n[GRAPHICS]- The game is pretty. It's not meant to have top-notch graphics
hoursPlayed: the developers wanted to make a fun game that's really cheap and can run on computers that are in mint-condition.\n\n[IMPROVEMENTS AND SUGGESTIONS]- Some weapons are clearly better than others. Anyone that has played Minimum for at least 15 minutes can honestly say that the swords are too op. I believe that swords should be at least half of the power that they currently have. I have purchased the grenade launcher and the fork launcher

reviewText:
Review: Alpha State and Focus on Low Skill Kills

First the good things. The game's graphics are, at least for my taste, very nice. And the low poly design, along with some more optimizations, could allow this game to have very low system requirements. It's potentially the only recent shooter i could run at a constant and stable 120fps/hz.

A little downside here, the game seems to be locked at 90 fps, which is a bit sad in times of 120Hz monitors. Probably an engine limitation, but most likely one that could be changed. Maybe even in the config files if one looks for it.

Also, the combination of a shooter with a moba, is extremely nice. Huge addictive potential here. The Titan game mode is spot on and could even survive as a single gametype in a shooter.

Unfortunately, that's already all good there is to say for the moment. So now to the weak sides.

First of all, they claim to have left early access. But this game is not even in Beta stage. In a Beta, most of the features are already there. In this game most feats are still placeholders. So what we got here is an alpha build.

The game's weakest point is, unfortunately, the combat part. Everything you found in the past 10 years in serious shooters, that was counted by top players as skill free, honorless or plain trolling, is what Minimum promotes at the moment.

That the weapon sounds, like the AR, sound like pea shooters, could be forgiven. But that the strongest tactic" ingame is

reviewText:
Oh my god. Why. This game is borderline BROKEN. Well first, this game is fun BUT ONLY WHEN PLAYING HORDE MODE!!! Horde mode is really the only mode that doesn't have Level 5 Katana rushers charging at you every minute. Katanas are what breaks the game.

Reasons:
Level 1 Katana takes 3-4 strikes to kill.
Katanas make you impossible to hit especially when the frames are down, but I'll ge to that.
Katanas give you a speed boost.
WHAT WERE YOU THINKING?!?!?! Absolutely not! How I think this situation should be remedied. Katanas give you a -30% health detriment. No speed bonus. (Why would you need a speed bonus when your katana has a built-in dash function already?)

Okay, I think I've covered the Katanas. Now onto the snipers. VERY, VERY HARD. Do not come into this game thinking you'll be blowing robot's heads off left and right. No. The headshot hitbox is TINY. Honestly, come on. You're zooming around the battlefield at 30 MPH and the hitbox is literally the size of the head, which I get, because why should you be able to kill someone with a headshot when it would normally go right past their ear? Well, it's impossible to hit. And snipers take 2-3 shots to kill.
How to remedy: Snipers get a 40% faster rate of fire. PLEASE IT IS SO SLOW. Second, Make a sniper 1-2 shot kill. Third, expand the headshot hitbox.

Okay, now those frames I was talking about.
My computer is overkill when it comes to this. Specs: Processer-3.16ghz Graphics-Radeon HD7790. More than enough? Yes. Soo, why am I getting choppy frames? I can play Battlefield 3 at 60FPS on Ultra, and this simple graphical game can only run at 30 fps avg with 10 fps frame drops? C'mon... I think this should have stayed in Beta a bit longer to smooth out these problems.

I wouldn't advise buying this game until a patch comes in because you'll just end up screaming and throwing your mouse at the wall.

But it is a fun game, just really, really, broken!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its an early acess game no doubt about that, but the gameplay is a lot of fun.
There arent many multiplayer third person shooters out there that i enjoy, tribes ascend being the only exception.

Things i like about this game.
- Ingame progression with craftable armour during matches:
ex: less health for more damage, less health for speed etc...
- allows for unique builds way more unique than other TPSs.

- Main Weapon upgrades upon killing an enemy
- forces you to be on the ofensive.

- Art style
- while minimilistic you can indentify what kind of armour the enemy has and know what kind of build they are making.

- Progression outside of a match
- with the 3 resource types you gain when playing you can craft new weapons and in the future slot in upgrades in them.

Things i dislike about this game.
- Balance
- theres some severe balance issues on some weapons nothing that can`t be fixed with time.
- Few game modes
- Lack of a proper match making
- Bugs

These things i dislike are usual with early acess games im sure they can be fixed with time, however i can say the game is stable in its current state ive been able to play with ease.

So if you are looking for a cool online TPS to play with your friends this is the game for you, if your still unsure after what`ve said then wait until the game is released. Cheers and happy gaming ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A normal match for me in MINIMUM
Choose Katana Loadout
Hold Shift
Click people with my Katana
Get full Beserker armor loadout
Upgrade it
Click people with my dual flaming katana's
Run away when I'm just about to die and survive
Then get blasted by a random grenade
Rinse, and repeat.

...That may sound boring, but it's incredibly fun.
If you want a game where you can just click people with swords while they're shooting you and kill them with barely enough health, get this game! It's quite fun. :3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minimum gives players exactly that. A bare minimum game without any high resolution details or environments because it doesn't need them. On it's own it already outshines other titles of the same genre. With objectives and game modes so simplisitc all that needs to be done is grab your gun and run into action. Titan Mode pits two mechanical behemoths against one another as players run around collecting crystals to help stengthen their massive ally all while blowing away the opposite team in blocky destruction. Customizable loadouts, armor selections and schematic crafting add to strategy and overall enjoyment.
More than worth the money and with future improvements already on the way, this can only get better.

A few suggestions for the devs
- Implement a proper level matching system. Basically pitting players together of the equal level and skill.

- Block off spawn containers once a player exits them. Too many people exploit the invulnerable aspect of them and shoot others while protected. Or at least prevent shooting from within them.

- Lower sword melee damage. Base damage on swords seems a bit OP for single blades, dual blades can be an exception.

- Armor crafting should be a sperate loadout option same as weapons. This can allow players to know what they want ahead of time and not hold up their teams with decisions. Armor leveling should be done at the respawn screen.

- Tweak gun accuracy

- Add interchangable mods to weapon loadouts

reviewText:
Minimum is a game where players in teams of five fight against another team, upgrading weapons, armor and their titan. Each team has one titan, which respawns shortly after death, and it's up to each team to defend their titan, while attacking the other, in the hopes of pushing their titan towards victory. It's a dynamic variation on the 'ARTS/MOBA' formula.
This game style works great, and is a tonne of fun but there are a few issues that need to be brought up.
1. Nobody likes to communicate in this team game where co-operation is nearly always vital to victory.
2. The game gives you the opportunity to get kills (which lets you upgrade your weapons and equipment while simultaneously getting score), or focus on killing or upgrading the titans (which lets you win the game). Being a video game, played by imperfect people, people often focus on getting kills instead of winning the game.
3. It's really quite irritating that a player needs to grind to try out new things, and considering the fact that the balance can often end up wonky, it feels like Minimum asks for too much time.

reviewText:
Now that Minimum is back up, I've decided to change my review.

Minimum is a pretty awesome game, with fun gameplay and a creative array of weaponry.
Pro's:
*Nice map and entity design.
*Creative weapons and armour, yes I know I'm repeating myself.
*Option to play as a male or female, which I know some people find important.
*Titan mode is fun to play and the Titans are pretty awe inspiring when they clash.
*Only real learning curve is learning how to counter melee. (Don't listen to those who complain melee is too overpowered, it is very easy to counter with the right weaponry and with enough practice)

Con's:
*The inventory whipe kind of killed it for me, I had spent a long time obtaining my items and while they said that they made all cosmetics/items craftable, some of my favourites are actually not craftable, such as the harvest sickles and the pumpkin grenades.
*Australian's may have a hard time playing as the player hosted servers can get quite lag, but its usually not unbearable.
*Last I checked the co-op survival mode, I believe it was called Horde mode or something, was currently not working, which sucks because it used to be very fun.


While the cons I've listed may seem to outweigh the pro's, this is really not the case. Minimum is a very fun game and I can't wait till it's completely restored to its former glory :)

Minimum was one of my favourite games.
However I would not recommend buying it (not that you can) in it's current state due to:

#1 (This is the most important issue) The servers have been down for what seems like an eternity, you cannot actually play the game should you buy it![/b]

#2 Prior to the server issues the new developers did not release that much new content. They redid some maps and released a couple new maps, but didn't add any new weapons or armour. (Not that the old developer were any better, as prior to the new developers taking ownership of the game they had not released anything new for quite some time). The last content update I remember was an april fools joke! When they added an invisible weapon and armour (the promo for said armour looked awesome, shame they didn't just make that armour)

#3 Prior to the server issues the community was very small. Quite often you'd end up being put on a server with bots rather than one of the few servers with people on them. This was not always the case, as the community used to be huge before the old devs stopped making new content.

Minimum was an amazing game and should they fix all the problems and actually bring the servers back online and start releasing new content (it would be a lot easier if they just hosted directly through steam like some other games) then go ahead and buy it, you won't regret it. But sadly it doesn't look like that time is coming any time soon :(

Thankyou for reading my review!

reviewText:
Minimum is a 3rd person multiplayer shooter that uses a minimilistic aesthetic with blocky shapes and solid colors. My friends and I picked it up over the steam summer sale while looking for some simple games we could play together. We found the matchmaking to be buggy, but still fun.

The main mechanic of the game involves you picking up powerups that drop from killed enemy's that upgrade your weapons up to 3 times, giving them more damage/new mechanics, as well as collecting materials to craft/upgrade armor sets. Powerups are lost on death but armor remains.

It has 3 game modes: Team Deathmatch, Horde mode, and a mode called Titan, where both teams try to escort a giant robot into the enemy base to destroy a power core. We mostly just played Titan mode, and had a fun time.

There are some pretty cool weapons like mine launchers and laser rifles, though some of them are imbalanced*Cough*Bouncechaingun*Cough*, meaning someone like me (Completely average at best) can stomp even people who are much higher skill level. Some, like the Cryo Sniper, are so weak/Hard to use that it makes it difficult to complete quests that require kills with that weapon.

There was an issue with rubberbanding, sometimes the servers lag out a little bit and makes everyone jump around, but it only happened maybe once a match, if that. The matchmaking as a group is a mess. Sometimes the group leader gets into a game while everyone else is stuck in a lobby, sometimes invites would not bring you into the group, and it seems the game won't put you on the same team if you have more than 3 players in your group.

TLDR: Fun, but buggy. Play it, if you don't mind dealing with bugs

reviewText:
Minimum's my go-to multiplayer game. It mixes third-person shooters with light MOBA elements in an elegant, action focused way. It’s well paced, and I find that matches tend to go back-and-forth; it's pretty rare to get completely steam-rolled.

Having to pick between killing off the enemy Titan, defending your Titan, farming creeps, choosing when to craft, or going in for kills to power-up your attacks makes each game feel pretty fresh. The lighting and particle effects are gorgeous. There's tons of loving details on each of the maps, like everyone has unique Titans, a cool visual theme and a something that differentiates itself gameplay-wise from the others.

I think the texture-less style looks great in motion. Since they don't have to worry about loading textures, they go over the top with the Enlighten engine and detailed, blocky particle effects. Despite being built out of squares, there's really lot of style in the maps, weapons and armor.

reviewText:
Minimum's my go-to multiplayer game. It mixes third-person shooters with light MOBA elements in an elegant, action focused way. It’s well paced, and I find that matches tend to go back-and-forth; it's pretty rare to get completely steam-rolled.

Having to pick between killing off the enemy Titan, defending your Titan, farming creeps, choosing when to craft, or going in for kills to power-up your attacks makes each game feel pretty fresh. The lighting and particle effects are gorgeous. There's tons of loving details on each of the maps, like everyone has unique Titans, a cool visual theme and a something that differentiates itself gameplay-wise from the others.

I think the texture-less style looks great in motion. Since they don't have to worry about loading textures, they go over the top with the Enlighten engine and detailed, blocky particle effects. Despite being built out of squares, there's really lot of style in the maps, weapons and armor.

reviewText:
This game is flawed in a myriad of ways, but the most important one is this: it's boring. So incredibly boring. The variety of the weapons and the level design is so low you've pretty much seen it all within an hour of playing.

This game is not fairThere's this idiotic system where kills upgrade your weapon, but dying resets it. This means the rich get richer and the poor stay poor. While I enjoy a good hunt on a player who's topping the charts, it should be about skill - not whoever gets the lucky first kill. Once someone gets ahead, the rest of his team picks up the spoils for his kills and get equally beefy. This means the match is pretty much decided by this point. Armor stays between lives, but most of the options are more of a trade-off than a downright improvement like the weapon upgrades.

You need a pretty beefy machine to run thisDo not be fooled by the game's lack of textures and low polygon count; your system will struggle like a moped trying to haul an elephant, and the fact that the elephant appears to be wearing a corset doesn't help very much. Even the main menu isn't smooth. I run a Radeon 7670M for a graphics card, which is not much but enough to run most games at low to medium settings smoothly. It can run Far Cry 3 no problem. But this game... even with everything set to minimum (including turning shadows off completely and running at a lower resolution), this game STILL didn't hit the stable 60 FPS mark. 30 FPS may be fine for some games, but this game is very twitchy; not to the extend of, say, Doom, but twitchy enough you're at a disadvantage running at anything below stable 60 FPS.

It isn't finishedEven the tutorial text says features are still missing. Besides, there's plenty of bugs. I often got a second aiming reticule drawn on screen and was unable to get rid of it, leaving me to guess as to which one was the one which actually indicated where my bullets will go. If the match starts while you're in the menus it'll force you back to the main menu. Energy cores often disappear when titans hit them. The news on the main menu displays 'Lorem ipsum' text while it loads. When you select 'titan' as the game mode and hit the server browser, it'll take you to a shoddy webpage and show you all game modes anyway. Oh, and there's no server names or ping display, making it very likely you'll pick a server halfway across the world with terrible lag.

Some minor annoyancesThe game's own account system which the unnecessary password restrictions (it needs to contain at least 7 characters which one capital letter and one number). The keyboard input lag when entering said password. The unexplained glow on the titans when they first spawn (I'm assuming this means they're invulnerable at that time). Stats on the weapons (damage, firerate, etc.) are nowhere to be found, making your guess as to which weapon to unlock next as good as any. The sheer number of different pick-ups that all look the same, especially in the heat of the moment. Nowhere is it explained that health regenerates (it becomes apparent pretty fast, but I'd sooner associate making someone glow with a power-up, not being low on health). Aim assist and mouse smoothing are on by default. The giant hitboxes on titans, making it impossible to shoot enemies behind them. The jerky animations on the titans. The ledges that look like you don't have to jump over them, but you do. There's no hit indicator on the titan. You get the point. I also find the 3rd person view very cumbersome on a twitchy shooter like this, but that may be personal.

ConclusionsNope. Don't get this. Save your money. Even if you can stand all the aforementioned problems, the gameplay really isn't that good. There's only so many weapons and they're all slight variations on a simple sniper, shotgun, launcher, or sword. The levels are all very similar. Games are decided way too quickly. It's simply boring. The idea with the titans and the creeps is interesting (though nothing new), but the execution is just abysmal. If you're looking for an FPS with a little bit of MOBA mixed in (like I was), Titanfall really does the whole creep thing a lot better, and you can actually pilot the titans in that game. If you want the big titan to protect and move forward, Team Fortress 2's cart mode is vastly superior (not to mention free and runs like a dream on old hardware).

Nothing to see here, move along.

reviewText: STAY AWAY, I REPEAT STAY AWAY, Unless you have endless time and an ultra computer, id advise NOT to buy this game.\n\nIt has some good points though; It is a MOBA (Up to you whether that is a good or bad thing) And the graphics are pretty cool in my opinion. Also currently the game is down indefinetly, so, you wont be playing anyways

reviewText: Minimum is a game that combines a third-person shooter (but it plays like a FPS) with MOBA aspects. At first, it doesn't seem to interesting, but look up some videos on gameplays and you'll see just how diverse it is. I've played it for less than 2 weeks now, and I'm loving it so far. Great game to either play a couple short rounds and turn it off or to play extensively to gather new weapons and armor.\nPlus, this game needs more publicity. There are only about 600 of us who play this game. You tend to run into the same people in matches. So definitely tell your friends about it if you think they might like it. Enjoy the game!

reviewText:
This game is is an Oxymoron. It's called minimum due to what graphics you work with but the game is far from minimum. It has 3 modes Team Death Match, Titan, and Horde mode. I've spent my time in only Team Death Match and Titan. I've enjoyed both and hope to have friends to play this game with as well, but I have noticed a few bothers.
1. The game has this weird tendency to not show the right scores. (Like for example, it'll show my kills and score, but the rest of my team will be blank throughout the scoreboard.)
2. The game doesn't allow you to change your load-outs while in game, while i think that's a small standard, it didn't bother me that much
3. Some weapons are OP, some weapons are crappy, and some are exceptional (Opinions vary)
4. If you choose to use katanas/swords often, prepare to see sword noob" for the whole game

Other than those small annoyances
date: i thoroughly enjoy this game and actually plan on playing it every time I go home.\n9.5/10"

reviewText:
About Minimum.
It seems like I spent enough time playing Minimum to review the game's pros and cons. Actually its not a bad game, don't let the cover judge the book. but it has its share of flaws. Down below I will list up all the things I noticed through our game session with friends. But first.

Pros / Cons Just a quickie..

Pros.
Great concept. [The Titan gamemode in this case]
Interesting game styles.
Fast paced action.
Minimalism done right.
Teamwork needed to win.
Crafting and Market mechanism.
Awesome visuals.
That oughta' summed up the game.

Cons
The actions sometimes become unpredictable. [eg. Cutting people for an hour and dont die]
Lag spikes and low framerate on 4+cores and 4gb ram
Hitboxes for objects too big. [Sentry, Titans ... Can't move away beside them]
If playing in a party, It mostly never gives you the same team. Happens with 3+ people.
I got this game for 5€ in the Team Pack for me and my friends, And we didn't /entirely/ regret getting the game, But it is good, Because it packs enough adrenaline it pulls you back to play more until you eventually tire out. It has badass swordplays, Sick gunfights and OP sniper shooting ranges. Like mentioned, The only setback is the lack of optimalisation. Even for a game with such low graphics can lag hard on good computers such as mine or my friends'. It kinda ruins the fun, But surely makes up later in-game. In overall, Buy the game to support the developers. It has room for development.

I'd say: 7/10. Great game.

reviewText:
One of the best multiplayer games I've played in a LONG time. I'm incredibly picky about my multiplayer shooters and I tend to dislike the typical war-shooter copy paste that's going around nowadays. Minimum is a barebones shooter where your skill is determined by how fast you can maneuver and how well you can aim.

Minimum is a fast-paced, strategic twitch shooter with solid, simplistic gameplay and so much more to come. There IS a community playing this game right now,  and people do keep up with it. It only takes about 4 seconds to connect to a match with all 10 people. The developers DO release updates fairly often, and they're high quality and expansive. I bought the game when it came out and even before the content they've added the game was good.

Things to like:

- The art style fits the game very well. The game doesn't have any sort of premise, so it doesn't try to fit any strict stylistic rules. The result: Firemen astronauts with Barney heads being attacked by raptors.

- At the same time, the environments look very good. The map design is fluid and clean while having tremendous asthetic appeal. Maps have a well-organized balance of long range and close quarters areas.

- Gameplay is very solid and clean. No frills, just skills. There are guns, giant grenade launchers and flaming swords to fit any playstyle. The better you are at aiming in two dimensions (something most modern shooters don't train you for) the better you'll be at this game.

- Developers talk with the community! There's a thread on steam regarding weapon balancing and ideas, there's a website with forums for users to talk with developers, and the devs listen!

- Matches have incredibly good back and forth. I've played matches where my team was seconds from losing only to take the next ten minutes making a coordinated effort pushing back and winning the match.

- Movement is fast and smooth, akin to playing scout in Team Fortress 2. Except now you can play as a scout with flaming swords and a sniper rifle.

- If you don't like multiplayer (or just need a break), there's a really fun horde mode where you face off against ninjas, raptors and knights.

- It isn't free to play! This means you can actually have fun! Players can't buy weapons to have an advantage over you. There are skins for sale in game, but they're actually easy enough to get without spending any money. Because of Minimum's integration with steam's inventory system, you can trade and sell items you get by playing for skins you might want. I traded a few weapons for a pretty kickass shinobi armor set that I use all the time.

Things to be aware of:

- Balancing is a little tricky at the moment. It's easy to get frustrated at players that have the game figured out a little better than you might.

- Getting kills buffs you, dying detriments you. This sounds frustrating, but with the way the game is balanced it isn't too much of a challenge. If you take time to practice and figure out what works best for you, it won't matter that you were killed and lost your level five weapon because you'll know how to earn it back.

- Obviously still some bugs and lag issues, as this game is still being developed. Getting rubberbanded every few matches is a little annoying but I'm sure it will be resolved eventually. However, the servers are generally very good. I usually have a ping of 20ms or less.

So I hope me writing this enourmous review will convince a few people to pick up this game while it's on sale. It's only $4 right now, and we could always use more players.
